intro: Chorizanthe andersonii, commonly known as Anderson's choris, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Amaranthaceae family and is characterized by its annual life cycle and succulent, hairy stems. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers that are clustered in dense inflorescences, often resembling a spiky structure. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in sandy or rocky soils. Its botanical features make it well adapted to drought conditions and it plays a role in supporting local pollinators.
